<script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
var theForm = document.forms['form'];
if (!theForm) {
    theForm = document.form;
}
function __doPostBack(eventTarget, eventArgument) {
    if (!theForm.onsubmit || (theForm.onsubmit() != false)) {
        theForm.__EVENTTARGET.value = eventTarget;
        theForm.__EVENTARGUMENT.value = eventArgument;
        theForm.submit();
    }
}
//]]>
</script>

            <!-- Navigation -->
            

<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/css/navigation.css" />
<link href="font.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />

<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js"></script>

<script>
    $(document).ready(function () {
        // =====================
        // Desktop Navigation
        // =====================
        var lastScrollTop = 0;
        var navigationHeight = $('.navigation').height(); // Get the height of the navigation div
        var pixelToleranceDown = navigationHeight * 1.10; // Set pixel tolerance for scrolling down
        var pixelToleranceUp = navigationHeight * 0.50; // Set pixel tolerance for scrolling up

        $(window).on('scroll', function () {
            var currentScrollTop = $(this).scrollTop();
            var scrolledDistance = Math.abs(lastScrollTop - currentScrollTop);

            if (currentScrollTop > lastScrollTop) {
                // Scrolling down
                if (scrolledDistance >= pixelToleranceDown) {
                    $('.desktop-nav-menu-items').slideUp(); // Hide navigation
                    lastScrollTop = currentScrollTop;
                }
            } else {
                // Scrolling up
                if (scrolledDistance >= pixelToleranceUp) {
                    $('.desktop-nav-menu-items').slideDown(); // Show navigation
                    lastScrollTop = currentScrollTop;
                }
            }
        });

        // =====================
        // Hover Navigation for Entire Desktop Navigation
        // =====================
        $('.desktop-nav-headers').hover(
            function () {
                // Mouse enters the area of the desktop navigation headers
                $('.desktop-nav-menu-items').stop(true, true).slideDown();
            },
            function () {
                // Mouse leaves the area of the desktop navigation headers
                $('.desktop-nav-menu-items').stop(true, true).slideUp();
            }
        );

        // =====================
        // Mobile Navigation
        // =====================
        // Hide the mobile navigation items initially
        //$('.mobile-nav-items').hide();

        // Click event for the mobile menu
        $('.mobile-menu').click(function () {
            // Ensure we're in mobile view
            if ($(window).width() <= 768) {
                // Toggle the visibility of the mobile navigation container
                $('.mobile-nav-container').toggle();
            
                // Toggle 'no-scroll' class on body only if the nav container is visible
                if ($('.mobile-nav-container').is(':visible')) {
                    $('body').addClass('no-scroll');
                } else {
                    $('body').removeClass('no-scroll');
                }
            }
        });

        // Close button click event
        $('.close-btn').click(function () {
            $('.mobile-nav-container').hide();
            $('body').removeClass('no-scroll');
        });

        // Function to hide mobile navigation on resize to desktop width
        function handleResize() {
            if ($(window).width() > 768) {
                $('.mobile-nav-container').hide();
                $('body').removeClass('no-scroll');
            }
        }

        // Call handleResize on window resize
        $(window).resize(handleResize);

        // Call handleResize on initial load
        handleResize();
});
</script>

                    <div>
	<table class="RegularTable" cellspacing="0" rules="all" border="1" id="MainContent_gvMissionTable" style="border-color:#E4E6E6;font-family:Helvetica;font-size:10pt;width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;">
		<tr align="left" style="color:White;background-color:#0E2D6D;">
			<th scope="col"><a href="javascript:__doPostBack(&#39;ctl00$MainContent$gvMissionTable&#39;,&#39;Sort$missionNameShort&#39;)" style="color:White;">Mission</a></th><th scope="col"><a href="javascript:__doPostBack(&#39;ctl00$MainContent$gvMissionTable&#39;,&#39;Sort$missionAgenciesClean&#39;)" style="color:White;">Agency</a></th><th scope="col"><a href="javascript:__doPostBack(&#39;ctl00$MainContent$gvMissionTable&#39;,&#39;Sort$missionStatus&#39;)" style="color:White;">Status</a></th><th align="right" scope="col"><a href="javascript:__doPostBack(&#39;ctl00$MainContent$gvMissionTable&#39;,&#39;Sort$launchDate&#39;)" style="color:White;">Launch date</a></th><th align="right" scope="col"><a href="javascript:__doPostBack(&#39;ctl00$MainContent$gvMissionTable&#39;,&#39;Sort$eolDate&#39;)" style="color:White;">EOL date</a></th><th scope="col">Applications</th><th scope="col">Instruments</th><th scope="col">Orbit details &amp; URL</th>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=786">COSMIC-2B (Polar)</a></b><br />COSMIC-2B (Polar)<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a> / UCAR</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Cancelled</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;"></td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;"></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">This is a radio occultation mission supporting meteorology and ionosphere &amp; climate measurements. The 12-satellite COSMIC-2A/2B constellation (6 equatorial and 6 polar) will produce over 4 times the daily total of occultation events as COSMIC-1 (3000 versus 12,000). This provides the capability to reconstruct the 3D ionospheric electron density structures for ionospheric space weather monitoring within a dramatically short data accumulation period. TGRS will receive signals from GPS, Galileo, and Glonass. COSMIC-2B will be a ride-share mission; the listed orbital parameters are desired and TBC.  At present, the U.S. portion of the COSMIC-2B program is unfunded, and alternatives are being pursued.
</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1725">TGRS</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: <br />Altitude: 720 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: 72 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: TBD<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="http://www.cosmic.ucar.edu/" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=881">ESSA-1</a></b><br />Environmental Science and Services Administration - 1<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Mission complete</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">03 Feb 1966</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">12 Jun 1968</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The ESSA-1 satellite provided cloud-cover photography to the US&#39;s National Meteorological Center for the purpose of preparing operational weather analyses and forecasts. The spacecraft was designed and configured exactly the same as NIMBUS-1. The total weight of the spacecraft was 912 pounds.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1826">FPR</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1839">VCS-WA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: <br />Altitude: <br />Period: <br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: <br />Links: </td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=394">SCISAT-1</a></b><br />SCISAT-I/ACE<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=5">CSA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a> / WMO / ECCC</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (nominal)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">12 Aug 2003</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Mar 2026</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The SCISAT satellite has been in continuous spaceflight operation since 2003. It now measures over sixty (60) atmospheric species at still one of the worlds highest vertical resolutions possible, and includes ozone, ozone depleting substances, all major greenhouse gases, and HFCs. Many of these species are measured by no other instrument or satellite world-wide, making Canada the sole provider of these datasets globally. As of 2024, the objectives of the mission remain to broadly assist in monitoring the UN Montreal Protocol, the Kigali Amendment, the Paris Climate Agreement, and the Canadian Environmental Protection Act.  Specific objectives include to assess the quality of model predictions for: ECs UV forecasting system, atmospheric carbon transport, and climate-chemistry process studies.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=701">ACE-FTS</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=702">MAESTRO</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 650 km<br />Period: 97.7 mins<br />Inclination: 74 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 365 days<br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/satellites/scisat/default.asp" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="http://www.ace.uwaterloo.ca/data.php">data access</a></td>

Spacecraft orbit lowering and passivation was completed on March 20, 2024. The Mission Closeout Phase will continue until September 30, 2025, when all algorithms and reprocess will be finalized, and the final dataset archived. </td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=649">CPR (CloudSat)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 686 km<br />Period: 98.3 mins<br />Inclination: 98.2 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: 13:45<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="http://cloudsat.atmos.colostate.edu/" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="https://search.earthdata.nasa.gov/search?q=CloudSat

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=944">FireBIRD 1 (TET-1)</a></b><br />Technologie-Erprobungstrger 1 / Technology Experiment Carrier 1 (TET-1)<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=30">DLR</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Mission complete</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">22 Jul 2012</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">30 Sep 2019</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The FireBIRD mission uses the TET-1 (Technologie-Erprobungstr&#228;ger 1;Technology Experiment Carrier 1) and BIROS (Bi-spectral InfraRed Optical System) satellites to detect high temperature events on Earths surface. They can also precisely capture small, low energy events thanks to the sensitivity of the sensors and the high precision and resolution. These might include heat irregularities such as volcanoes, burning ships, industry hotspots, gas flares, chemical heat generation and smouldering fires.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1908">HSRS (FireBIRD 1 (TET-1))</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 420 km<br />Period: 92.8 mins<br />Inclination: 97.6 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.dlr.de/content/en/missions/firebird.html

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=730">ePOP on CASSIOPE</a></b><br />Enhanced Polar Outflow Probe on the CAScade, Smallsat and IOnospheric Polar Explorer<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / MDA / University of Calgary</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (extended)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">29 Sep 2013</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2025</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The ePOP probe observes the Earths ionosphere, where space meets the upper atmosphere. The instruments are used in conjunction with other satellite-based and ground-based instruments to analyze radio wave propagation in the ionosphere, measure the densities of ionized particles, and observe the aurora from space, all as they respond to space weather. The orbit is 450 km to 1250 km. Note: MDA is the owner and University of Calgary is the operator. Since December 2021, spacecraft is in slow rotation due to 3 damaged reaction wheels, but continues to collect science data.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1656">CER</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1705">FAI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1707">GAP</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1708">IRM</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1709">MGF</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1710">NMS</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1706">RRI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1704">SEI</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 450 km<br />Period: 101 mins<br />Inclination: 81 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="http://epop.phys.ucalgary.ca/" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="https://epop.phys.ucalgary.ca/data/">data access</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=913">DubaiSat-2</a></b><br />DubaiSat-2<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;">MBRSC / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=207">UAE SA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (extended)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">21 Nov 2013</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2025</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">DubaiSat-2 is a continuation of the Knowledge Transfer Programme that started with the manufacturing of DubaiSat-1. It provides satellite imaging services at a resolution of 1 meter to meet the needs of local and international clients.  The mission objectives are: to develop a mini satellite system of less than 300 kg for Earth observation; to provide electro-optical imagery, that can be commercialized, of the UAE and other areas with a spatial resolution of 1m PAN (panchromatic) and 4m MS (multispectral) from a reference orbit of 600 km altitude; to develop and implement new technologies, not used in DubaiSat-1, that can be used in future space programmes; and, to continue training for UAE&#39;s space programme.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1887">HiRAIS</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 600 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: 97.1 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 8 days<br />LST: 10:30:00<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://mbrsc.ae/en/page/dubai-sat-2" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=552">Sentinel-2 A</a></b><br />Sentinel-2 A<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (nominal)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">23 Jun 2015</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jul 2025</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Sentinel-2 mission delivers high-resolution optical multispectral imagery across 13 spectral bands in the visible to shortwave infrared, with spatial resolutions up to 10 meters and a revisit period of 5 days. This data supports a wide range of applications, including precision agriculture, food security, ecosystems monitoring, disaster management (e.g., volcanoes, wildfires, floods, landslides), water quality assessment, or observing anthropogenic methane emissions.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=940">MSI (Sentinel-2)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 786 km<br />Period: 100.7 mins<br />Inclination: 98.62 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 10 days<br />LST: 10:30<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-2/overview" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=945">FireBIRD 2 (BIROS)</a></b><br />Bispectral InfraRed Optical System (BIROS)<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=30">DLR</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Mission complete</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">22 Jun 2016</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">31 Dec 2020</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The FireBIRD mission uses the TET-1 (Technologie-Erprobungstr&#228;ger 1;Technology Experiment Carrier 1) and BIROS (Bi-spectral InfraRed Optical System) satellites to detect high temperature events on Earths surface. They can also precisely capture small, low energy events thanks to the sensitivity of the sensors and the high precision and resolution. These might include heat irregularities such as volcanoes, burning ships, industry hotspots, gas flares, chemical heat generation and smouldering fires.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 510 km<br />Period: 94.6 mins<br />Inclination: 97.4 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.dlr.de/content/en/missions/firebird.html

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=780">LIS-on-ISS</a></b><br />International Space Station/Lightning Imaging Sensor<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Mission complete</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">19 Feb 2017</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">30 Oct 2023</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Spare LIS unit from the TRMM mission. NASA selected the LIS spare hardware to fly to the space station in order to take advantage of the orbiting laboratorys high inclination. Will monitor global lightning for Earth science studies, provide cross-sensor calibration and validation with other space-borne instruments, and ground-based lightning networks. LIS will also supply real-time lightning data over data-sparse regions, such as oceans, to support operational weather forecasting and warning.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1877">LIS</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 405 km<br />Period: 90 mins<br />Inclination: 51 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: <br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="http://lightning.nsstc.nasa.gov/lis/" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="https://search.earthdata.nasa.gov/search?q=isslis">data access</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=687">SAGE-III-on-ISS</a></b><br />Stratospheric Aerosol and Gas Experiment (SAGE)-III/International Space Station (ISS)<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (extended)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">19 Feb 2017</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Sep 2026</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">1-year design life, 3-year Phase E goal. Refurbishment of the SAGE-III instrument and of a hexapod pointing platform, and accommodation studies. This mission flies on the ISS. Objective is to monitor the vertical distribution of aerosols, ozone, and other trace gases in the Earths stratosphere and troposphere to enhance our understanding of ozone recovery and climate change processes in the upper atmosphere. Extended mission to 2026 awarded in 2020.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1598">SAGE-III</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 405 km<br />Period: 90 mins<br />Inclination: 51 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: <br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://sage.nasa.gov/missions/about-sage-iii-on-iss/" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="https://search.earthdata.nasa.gov/search?q=SAGE III/ISS">data access</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=553">Sentinel-2 B</a></b><br />Sentinel-2 B<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (nominal)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">06 Mar 2017</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Apr 2027</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Sentinel-2 mission delivers high-resolution optical multispectral imagery across 13 spectral bands in the visible to shortwave infrared, with spatial resolutions up to 10 meters and a revisit period of 5 days. This data supports a wide range of applications, including precision agriculture, food security, ecosystems monitoring, disaster management (e.g., volcanoes, wildfires, floods, landslides), water quality assessment, or observing anthropogenic methane emissions.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=940">MSI (Sentinel-2)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 786 km<br />Period: 100.7 mins<br />Inclination: 98.62 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 10 days<br />LST: 10:30<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-2/overview" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

The main objectives of the KhalifaSat mission are to: develop a sub-meter resolution small satellite system to be used for global imaging and download; establish the necessary infrastructure for the development of the satellites in the UAE; and, contribute locally and internationally with value-added products and services derived from KhalifaSat images.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1888">KHCS</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 613 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: 97.13 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 8 days<br />LST: 13:30:00<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://mbrsc.ae/en/page/khalifa-sat" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

The FSSCat mission is based on two CubeSats, each about the size of a shoebox, that use state-of-the-art dual-microwave and multispectral sensors to measure, for example, soil  moisture, sea-ice extent and sea-ice thickness. 			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=968">LARES-2</a></b><br />LAser RElativity Satellite 2<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=1">ASI</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (nominal)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">13 Jul 2022</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Mar 2062</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Scientific objectives are the high accuracy measurement of the dragging of inertial frames due to the Earth&#39;s angular momentum, or Lense-Thirring effect, and a high precision test of the Earth&#39;s gravitomagnetic field with an accuracy greatly improved with respect to the previous LAGEOS and LARES missions. Gravitomagnetic field and dragging of inertial frames are predictions of Einstein&#39;s theory of General Relativity. In addition, LARES-2 will allow other measurements in General Relativity, geodesy and geodynamics.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1948">LCCRA (LARES-2)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 5892 km<br />Period: 226 mins<br />Inclination: 70 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.lares-mission.com/LARES_2.asp" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=923">EMIT-on-ISS</a></b><br />International Space Station/Earth Surface Mineral Dust Source Investigation (EMIT)<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Operational (extended)</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">14 Jul 2022</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jan 2031</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Imaging spectroscopy from the visible to short wavelength infrared (VSWIR) to close the gap in knowledge of the composition of the Earths&#39; mineral dust source regions.  Uses these new measurements with Earth System models to constrain the sign and magnitude of current dust-related radiative forcing at regional and global scales and predict the increase or decrease of available dust sources under future climate scenarios.  Deliver these first of their kind comprehensive measurements to the Earth science and applications community.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1901">EMIT</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 417 km<br />Period: 93 mins<br />Inclination: 51.6 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://earth.jpl.nasa.gov/emit/" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="https://earthdata.nasa.gov/eosdis/daacs/lpdaac">data access</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=986">AWS</a></b><br />Arctic Weather Satellite<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Commissioning</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">16 Aug 2024</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Aug 2029</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">AWS is the protoflight satellite for a planned constellation of meteorological microsatellites providing passive microwave soundings for global atmospheric temperature temperature and humidity profiles soundings in all weather conditions, with frequent revisits over the Arctic and Antarctic polar regions. This constellation (called EPS-Sterna, which is named after the latin name Sterna for the Arctic Tern) will consist of 3 orbital planes with 2 satellites in each orbital plane. With a nominal satellite lifetime of 5 years, a first launch in 2029 and 2 replenishments of each orbit plane, a minimum mission lifetime for the full system of 13 years will be achieved. Local Solar time for AWS is 09:00 - 11:00 and  EPS-Sterna Descending LST is  03:30, 07:30, 11:30.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1959">AWS Instrument</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 595 km<br />Period: 97 mins<br />Inclination: 97.79 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/Meteorological_missions/Arctic_Weather_Satellite" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="">data access</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=842">GeoCarb</a></b><br />Geostationary Carbon Cycle Observatory<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Cancelled</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">30 Jun 2025</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">30 Jun 2028</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The GeoCarb mission provides persistent daytime measurements from a geostationary orbit (85&#176; West +/- 10&#176;) of the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), carbon monoxide (CO), and it also provides measurements of solar-induced fluorescence (SIF). By measuring daily over the Americans (55&#176; N/S Latitude) CO2, CH4, and CO concentrations and SIF under changing conditions at fine spatial scales roughly (5kmx5km), GeoCarb enables determination of major anthropogenic sources of CO2 and CH4 and breakthrough investigations of their natural sources and sinks. This provides the basis for a transformational improvement in our understanding of the carbon cycle, and it demonstrates an effective approach to monitoring CO2 and CH4, the two most important greenhouse gasses that is synergistic with measurements from Low Earth Orbit (LEO).</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1784">Scanning Spectrometer (GeoCarb)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Geostationary<br />Altitude: 35786 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): 85<br />Asc/desc: <br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.ou.edu/geocarb" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=984">HydroGNSS</a></b><br />HydroGNSS-A and -B<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=2">UKSA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Oct 2025</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2031</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">This Scout mission, HydroGNSS, will provide measurements of key hydrological climate variables, including soil moisture, freezethaw state over permafrost, inundation and wetlands, and above-ground biomass, using a technique called Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) reflectometry. In doing so it will complement missions such as ESAs SMOS and Biomass, Copernicus Sentinel-1 and NASAs SMAP. Knowledge of these variables helps scientists understand climate change and contributes towards weather modelling, ecology mapping, agricultural planning and flood preparedness.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1939">SGR-ReSI-Z</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 550 km<br />Period: 95.6 mins<br />Inclination: 98.7 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 30 days<br />LST: 10:30<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eoportal.org/satellite-missions/hydrognss" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="">data access</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1454">Atlantic Constellation Pathfinder</a></b><br />Atlantic Constellation Pathfinder<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=2">UKSA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jul 2026</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jul 2031</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The Atlantic Constellation aims to provide more frequent coverage of European territories that could be affected by natural disasters or climate change and erosion, as well as support commercial enterprises such as agriculture. The programme differs from existing European constellation satellites such as Copernicus in that it would reduce revisit times from 3 days to 24 hours.  This Pathfinder will demonstrate the key technologies asociated with the project such as enhanced AI processesing and inter satellite links allowing tasking even when not above a ground station.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2132">MSI (Atlantic Constellation PF)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 570 km<br />Period: 95 mins<br />Inclination: 97.6 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 20 days<br />LST: 1899-12-30T03:30:00.000Z<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: </td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1017">INCUS</a></b><br />INvestigation of Convective UpdraftS<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Nov 2026</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jan 2029</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Characterize the relationship between Convective Mass Flux and atmospheric environmental properties by providing novel measurements of time-differenced profiles of radar reflectivity. 

INCUS objectives are to determine: (1) the predominant environmental properties controlling convective mass flux in tropical convective storms; (2) the relationship between convective mass flux and high anvil clouds; (3) the relationship between convective mass flux and the type and intensity of the extreme weather produced; and then to evaluate these relationships between convective mass flux and environmental factors, high anvil clouds, and extreme weather within weather and climate models.
Application: improve the nowcasting of rapidly developing convective storms by expanding the inputs to nowcasting systems.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1993">DAR (INCUS)</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1994">DMR (INCUS)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 500 km<br />Period: 94 mins<br />Inclination: 28.5 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: TBD<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://incus.colostate.edu/" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="TBD">data access</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1410">PolSIR</a></b><br />Polarized Submillimeter Ice-cloud Radiometer<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jan 2027</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jan 2029</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The goal of the PolSIR mission is to better characterize and understand the diurnal variability of tropical and sub-tropical ice clouds. PolSIR will provide key observational constraints on ice properties in climate models and enable modelers to develop more accurate cloud parameterizations.

The science and application objectives are to: (1) Constrain the seasonally influenced diurnal cycle amplitude, form, and timing of the ice water path (IWP) and particle diameter in tropical and sub-tropical ice clouds. (2) Determine the diurnal variability of ice clouds in the convective outflow areas and understand relation to deep convection. (3) Determine the relationship between shortwave and longwave radiative fluxes and the diurnal variability of ice clouds. (4) Enable improvement of climate models by providing novel observations of the diurnal cycle of ice clouds, ultimately leading to improved climate modeling skills and increased fidelity of climate forecasts in support of critical decision-making.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2083">PolSIR</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 475 km<br />Period: 94 mins<br />Inclination: 52 deg<br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: 1899-12-30T03:30:00.000Z<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: </td>
		</tr><tr>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1455">EPS-Sterna</a></b><br />EUMETSAT Polar System - Sterna<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Planned</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2029</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2042</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">EPS-Sterna is a EUMETSAT constellation of meteorological microsatellites providing passive microwave soundings for global atmospheric temperature temperature and humidity profiles soundings in all weather conditions, with frequent revisits over high latitude regions. EPS-Sterna (which is named after the latin name Sterna for the Arctic Tern) will consist of 3 orbital planes with 2 satellites in each orbital plane. With a nominal satellite lifetime of 5 years, a first launch in 2029 and several replenishments of each orbit plane, a minimum mission lifetime for the full system of 13 years will be achieved.
AWS is the protoflight of the constellation, the latter was developed  by ESA, the satellite of the EPS-Sterna will be recurrent models of the prototype (with minor modifications). 
 Local Solar time for AWS is 22:30 (TBC) and  EPS-Sterna Descending LST is  03:30, 07:30, 11:30.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 595 km<br />Period: 97 mins<br />Inclination: 97.79 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 9 days<br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eumetsat.int/eps-sterna" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1036">Sentinel ROSE-L A</a></b><br />Radar Observing System for Europe in L-band A<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Sep 2029</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Mar 2037</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">ROSE-L will provide day-and-night monitoring of land, oceans and ice offering more frequent imaging at high spatial resolution and sensitivity, to monitor soil moisture, precision farming, food security, forest biomass and changes to land use. 			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1044">Harmony</a></b><br />Harmony-A and -B<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2029</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2034</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Harmony will be dedicated to the observation and quantification of small scale motion and deformation (velocity gradient) fields, primarily, at the air-sea interface (winds, waves, and surface currents, including measurements over extreme events), of the solid Earth (tectonic strain), and in the cryosphere (glacier flows and surface height changes).
Primary mission objectives:
1. Air-sea interaction, tropical and extra-tropical cyclones, and ocean mesoscale and submesoscale processes;
2. Tectonic strain; and
3. Glacier and ice-sheet mass balance and glacier dynamics.
Harmony will make significant contributions to other science domains, including volcanoes, permafrost, landslides and several sea-ice objectives.                                    The space segment will consist of two companion satellites to Sentinel-1, each carrying a receive-only SAR instrument, complemented by a TIR payload. The companion satellites fly in two different configurations with Sentinel-1. In the stereo configuration, one companion is leading and the other is trailing Sentinel-1. The optimum distance to Sentinel-1 (stereo baseline) is determined from a complex trade-off on the performance of both instruments. One of the strongest drivers is the improved viewing geometry associated with large squint angles and both concepts therefore use a long baseline (350 km for Concept A and 400 km for Concept B).</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2021">Multiview Thermal-Infared</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2020">Passive Synthetic Aperture Radar</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 693 km<br />Period: 98.74 mins<br />Inclination: 98.19 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 12 days<br />LST: 18:00<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Ascending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eoportal.org/satellite-missions/harmony" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=982">TRUTHS</a></b><br />Traceable Radiometry Underpinning Terrestrial- and Helio- Studies (TRUTHS)<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=2">UKSA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Mar 2030</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Sep 2035</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">TRUTHS will provide ultra high accuracy International System of Units (SI-traceable) spectrally resolved measurements of incoming and Earth reflected solar radiation, globally sampled at 50 m spatial resolution as a benchmark for radiation budget and other climate indicators in the solar reflective domain e.g cloud, Albedo, Land products, Ocean colour, and carbon cycle. Designed explicitly as an operational climate mission TRUTHS in addition to its own data, provides reference calibration to other optical sensors operating in the spectral range 320 to 2400 nm, including amongst other &#39;new space&#39; sensors and the future GHG constellation, improving their performance and interoperability.  It also provides a radiometric SI-traceable anchor to existing post-launch calibration infrastructure such as deserts and the Moon. The mission additionally provides spectrally resolved and total solar irradiance measurements for climate and atmosphere/surface interaction studies.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1953">CSAR</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1954">HIS</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 610 km<br />Period: 96.9 mins<br />Inclination: 90 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 61 days<br />LST: 2023-09-12T11:37:39.024+1000<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: TBD<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/TRUTHS" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>

HAWC consists of three innovative Canadian instruments and a Canadian satellite that will be part of the international NASA-led Atmosphere Observing System (AOS). 			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1475">GEOSAR</a></b><br />Geosynchronous Synthetic Aperture Radar<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=1">ASI</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Considered</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2031</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2046</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Acquire SAR images from quasi geostationary orbit, in order to provide: continuous monitoring of fast evolving geophysical processes, over large areas and with time scales of the order of hours; pairs of daily interferometric images (two interferometric passes per day over the entire national territory) for DInSAR applications; acquisitions with sub-daily frequency for change detection applications with intervals of the order of hours; different line of sight compared to LEO SAR missions thanks to the predominant north-south observation geometry; rapid access time to the area of ??interest and rapid response to events, with almost immediate availability of the acquired data.
Main applications: monitoring of landslides and ground displacements, seismic and volcanic phenomena, terrain and infrastructure stability, flood mapping, soil moisture and water vapor maps.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Geostationary<br />Altitude: 35786 km<br />Period: 1436 mins<br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: 1 day<br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: </td>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=980">Geo-I1</a></b><br />Geostationary Extended Observations Imager 1<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Apr 2032</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2055</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">GeoXO will supply vital information to address major environmental challenges of the future in support of U.S. weather, ocean, and climate operations. 			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1387">MAGIC/MCDO</a></b><br />Mass-change And Geosciences International Constellation - Mass Change Designated Observable<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2032</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2040</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Mass-change And Geoscience International Constellation (MAGIC) concept based on NASA&#39;s Mass Change Designated Observable mission (MCDO). MAGIC/MCDO 2-sat constellation will measure fluctuations in Earths gravitational field, allowing the study of hydrological phenomena such as mass transport, as well as building on the success of previous missions in the field, such as the Gravity field and steady-state Ocean Circulation Explorer (GOCE) mission, the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE), and its follow-on mission, GRACE-FO. MAGIC will provide data continuity for the mass transport time series from these missions, as well as improvements in the temporal and spatial resolution of gravitational field mapping. This greater resolution in mapping Earths gravitational field will also allow enhanced study of mass transport, the shift of water mass between phases of the global water cycle, as mass transport has a calculable impact on gravitational field fluctuations.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2056">LTI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2099">MicroSTAR accelerometer</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 500 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: 65 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 7 days<br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: TBD<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eoportal.org/satellite-missions/magic" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1386">MAGIC/NGGM</a></b><br />Mass-change And Geosciences International Constellation - Next Generation Gravity Mission<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Planned</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2032</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2040</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Mass-change And Geoscience International Constellation (MAGIC) concept based on ESAs Next Generation Gravity Missions (NGGM). The objective of MAGIC is the long-term accurate monitoring of the temporal variations of Earths gravity field at high resolution in time (down to 3 days) and in space. MAGIC will observe Earth mass change and reinforce services in hydrology, cryosphere, oceanography, solid Earth, climate change and geodesy. The observables are the variations of the distance between two satellites, measured by a laser interferometer with sub-nanometre precision, and non-gravitational accelerations, to be separated from the gravity signal in the data processing, measured by accelerometers on each satellite. MAGIC represents the natural evolution in the provision of enhanced continuity of science and services with respect to predecessor missions like GRACE, GOCE and GRACE-FO and will be complementary to other Earth Explorer and Copernicus missions. The improvements expected in terms of spatial, temporal resolution and measurement accuracy shall pave the way to novel science and operational applications, such as monitoring of extreme events, warning for drought and flood events as well as geohazards.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2056">LTI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2099">MicroSTAR accelerometer</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 400 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: 70 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 7 days<br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: TBD<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eoportal.org/satellite-missions/magic" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1469">S3NGT-A</a></b><br />Sentinel-3 Next Generation Topography A<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Planned</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2033</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2041</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">The S3NGT mission aims at providing continuity of the Copernicus Sentinel-3 radar altimetry, while increasing the quantity and quality of products and service. It will also provide atmospheric aerosol profiles.
In addition, Radio Occultation profiles will be obtained to determine atmospheric temperature and humidity profiles using Galileo, GPS and Beidou.
LST is 18:00 (on an Ascending Node) ad at 06:00 (for a dawn-dusk orbit)

			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=589">MTG-I4 (imaging)</a></b><br />Meteosat Third Generation - Imaging Satellite 4<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2036</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Jun 2047</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Meteorology, climatology, atmospheric dynamics/water and energy cycles.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=885">FCI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=890">LI</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Geostationary<br />Altitude: 35779 km<br />Period: 1436 mins<br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): 0<br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eumetsat.int/meteosat-third-generation" target="_blank">mission site</a> | <a style="color:black" target="_blank" href="https://www.eumetsat.int/access-our-data">data access</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=848">Sentinel-5 C</a></b><br />Sentinel-5 C<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">May 2039</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Nov 2047</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Sentinel-5 will globally monitor key air quality trace gases, aerosols and UV index  in support of the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) at high spatial resolution and with a daily global revisit time.  The Sentinel-5C mission is carried on EPS-SG-A3.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1504">UVNS (Sentinel-5)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 820 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-5/overview" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=839">METOP-SG A3</a></b><br />EUMETSAT Polar System - Second Generation - atmosphere sounding and imaging satellite 3<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=30">DLR</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=4">CNES</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">May 2039</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Nov 2047</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Meteorology, climatology. EPS-SG-a carries the Sentinel-5 mission. 3 satellites.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1627">3MI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1626">IASI-NG</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=965">METimage</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1663">MWS</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1628">RO</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1504">UVNS (Sentinel-5)</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 824 km<br />Period: 101.4 mins<br />Inclination: 98.7 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 29 days<br />LST: 9:30<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eumetsat.int/metop-sg" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1458">Geo-I3</a></b><br />Geostationary Extended Observations Imager 3<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">May 2039</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2055</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">GeoXO will supply vital information to address major environmental challenges of the future in support of U.S. weather, ocean, and climate operations. The GeoXO mission will continue and expand observations provided by the GOES-R Series as NOAA&#39;s next generation of geostationary satellites.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2045">GXI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2046">LMX</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2047">OCX</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Geostationary<br />Altitude: 36000 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.nesdis.noaa.gov/next-generation-satellites/geostationary-extended-observations-geoxo" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=841">METOP-SG B3</a></b><br />EUMETSAT Polar System - Second Generation - microwave imaging satellite 3<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=4">CNES</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Feb 2040</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Aug 2048</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Meteorology, climatology. 3 satellites.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1662">ICI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1630">MWI</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1628">RO</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1631">SCA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 824 km<br />Period: 101.4 mins<br />Inclination: 98.7 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 29 days<br />LST: 9:30<br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: Descending<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.eumetsat.int/metop-sg" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1463">Sentinel-6 C</a></b><br />Sentinel-6 C<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=9">EUMETSAT</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=12">NASA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=114">COM</a> / <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=8">ESA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Planned</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2040</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">2046</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Sentinel-6 provides precision sea level, sea surface height, significant wave height, inland water heights and other products tailored to operational services in the ocean, climate, atmospheric and land Copernicus Services. It also provides enhanced continuity to the very stable time series of mean sea level measurements and ocean sea state after Jason-3.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1719">AMR-C</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2105">DGXX-S</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1720">GNSS POD Receiver</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1785">GNSS-RO Receiver</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1721">LRA (Sentinel-6)</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=1723">Poseidon-4 Altimeter</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Inclined, non-sun-synchronous<br />Altitude: 1343 km<br />Period: 112.4 mins<br />Inclination: 66.05 deg<br />Repeat cycle: 10 days<br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-6/overview" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1459">Geo-S2</a></b><br />Geostationary Extended Observations Sounder 2<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Nov 2040</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2055</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">GeoXO will supply vital information to address major environmental challenges of the future in support of U.S. weather, ocean, and climate operations. The GeoXO mission will continue and expand observations provided by the GOES-R Series as NOAA&#39;s next generation of geostationary satellites.</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:100px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2048">ACX</a>, <a style="color:#000000" href="../database/instrumentsummary.aspx?instrumentID=2049">GXS</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">Type: Geostationary<br />Altitude: 36000 km<br />Period: <br />Inclination: <br />Repeat cycle: <br />LST: <br />Longitude (if geo): <br />Asc/desc: N/A<br />Links: <a style="color:#000000" href="https://www.nesdis.noaa.gov/next-generation-satellites/geostationary-extended-observations-geoxo" target="_blank">mission site</a></td>
		</tr><tr>
			<td valign="top" style="color:White;background-color:#2A85AF;width:180px;"><b><a style="color:#FFFFFF" href="../database/missionsummary.aspx?missionID=1460">Geo-I4</a></b><br />Geostationary Extended Observations Imager 4<br /><br /></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:180px;"><a style="color:#000000" href="../database/agencysummary.aspx?agencyID=14">NOAA</a></td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:140px;">Approved</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Nov 2042</td><td align="right" valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:90px;">Dec 2055</td><td valign="top" style="background-color:LightBlue;width:200px;">GeoXO will supply vital information to address major environmental challenges of the future in support of U.S. weather, ocean, and climate operations. 		</tr>
